title: What happens next after Boris Johnson’s crucial Brexit bill is delayed
text:
Boris Johnson vows to press on despite losing a crunch vote on Brexit (Picture: AFP)

Boris Johnson has suffered a humiliating defeat after MPs voted to delay Brexit in a historic showdown in the House of Commons.

Opposition politicians voted for an amendment which now forces the Prime Minister to write to the EU and ask for an extension until January 31.

The Letwin amendment was backed by MPs who were critical of Boris Jonhnson’s deal because it did not contain legislation implementing withdrawal.

There were fears that even if the agreement got the green light, the legalities would not be completed by the end of the transition period.

This could have resulted in an accidental ‘no-deal’ – so former Tory minister Sir Oliver Letwin put down an amendment to prevent the UK crashing out.

However immediately after the PM lost the vote, he said he would still not negotiate the Brexit deadline, telling MPs ‘the law does not compel me to’.

This has thrown the whole Brexit process back into the arena of the uncertain – and it appears even MPs are confused about what happens next.

Meaningful vote

The government pulled a meaningful vote on Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal after the Letwin amendment was passed.

The PM has vowed to introduce legislation needed to implement his ‘excellent’ agreement in Parliament next week.

Earlier reports said he would seek to put his Brexit deal back to MPs on Tuesday, but Commons leader Jacob Rees-Mogg told has MPs this will be on Monday.

He made the statement shortly after the results of the Letwin amendment were announced, before leaving the chamber to cries of ‘outrageous’ and ‘dreadful’.

If the meaningful vote is passed, it means the UK will be leaving the EU on October 31 with Boris Johnson’s deal.

If it isn’t, it is likely Brexit will be delayed.

Brexit delay

Advertisement

Advertisement

In the meantime, Boris Johnson must write to the EU asking for an extension beyond October 31.

The Letwin amendment means that at midnight tonight, the Benn Act comes into force.

The law makes a no-deal Brexit illegal and requires Johnson to beg for an extra three months in the EU.

However, BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg says there is going to be a lot of arguing over the difference between asking for a delay and actually negotiating one.

Some in Whitehall think the PM is allowed to set out government policy in his letter.

Boris Johnson remains defiant after losing a crunch vote on Brexit (Picture: AFP)

It means that he could ask for a delay in one letter while also suggesting to EU leaders that they should not offer one in a separate letter.

A Number 10 spokesperson said: ‘Parliament has voted to delay Brexit yet again. The PM will not ask for an extension – he will tell EU leaders there should be no delays, they should reject Parliament’s letter asking for a delay, and we should get Brexit done on October 31 with our new deal’.

However this interpretation is being contested, and some predict the issue might end up in the High Court next week.
